1.tilte: Rachel Garcia, in limelight with Team USA, faces former UCLA teammates Sunday
1.discription:

Sports Awards at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills on Thursday, February 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Birmingham, Pasadena Star-News/SCNG)
 
 
UCLA pitcher Rachel Garcia wearing her national championship ring as she is named the 2019 LA Sports Awards Sportswoman of the Year by the Los Angeles Sports Council during the L.A. Sports Awards at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills on Thursday, February 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Birmingham, Pasadena Star-News/SCNG)
 
 
UCLA pitcher Rachel Garcia, right, is named the 2019 LA Sports Awards Sportswoman of the Year by the Los Angeles Sports Council during the L.A. Sports Awards at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills on Thursday, February 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Birmingham, Pasadena Star-News/SCNG)
 
 
UCLA softball coach Lisa Fernandez, left, stands with UCLA pitcher Rachel Garcia as she is named the 2019 LA Sports Awards Sportswoman of the Year by the Los Angeles Sports Council during the L.A. Sports Awards at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills on Thursday, February 20, 2020. (Photo by Keith Birmingham, Pasadena Star-News/SCNG)
 
 
UCLA’s Rachel Garcia pitches against Oklahoma during the first inning of Game 2 of the best-of-three championship series at the Women’s College World Series on Tuesday in Oklahoma City. Garcia was named the tournament MVP after leading the Bruins to their first national title since 2010. (AP Photo/Alonzo Adams)
 
 
BEVERLY HILLS >> In a backstage in a dressing room at the Beverly Hilton Hotel, an hour before the annual L.A. Sports Awards, Rachel Garcia was surrounded by family and friends. She wore a black dress with see-through sleeves and nude-colored heels — an outfit she had a friend approve of in advance. 

A makeup artist asked her to pull up the end of her dress a couple inches and began rubbing tinted lotion on her leg to prepare her for being on camera. Garcia looked confused. 

“You don’t do this often, do you?” 

Through all the accolades, including Collegiate Woman Athlete of the Year and most recently receiving the 2019 LA Sportswoman of the Year award by the Los Angeles Sports Council on Thursday, and all the media appearances over the past eight months, Garcia is still not used to all this. 
“I’m not gonna lie, this whole thing is not really my style,” Garcia said. “Dressing up is very hard for me.” 

It’s been a non-stop rollercoaster ride of emotional experiences for the UCLA softball pitcher. After leading the Bruins to the program’s 13th national championship in June, Garcia’s childhood dreams came true in October when she made the U.S. Olympic team for this summer’s 2020 Olympics in Tokyo. 

While the Palmdale native is learning what it takes to compete on the biggest stage, she understands this opportunity will forever impact the sport’s future, especially with the next stop on the ride being a collision of her two softball worlds in a Sunday exhibition game between Team USA and UCLA at 
“I feel like it’s never ending,” she said. “I feel a little overwhelmed not gonna lie. It’s a lot of stuff coming at me at once. I’m just super honored and humbled with what softball has provided me, just to be here to represent softball means the world to me right now.” 

Sunday’s game is just one stop on Team USA’s 66-game, 35-city ‘Stand Beside Her’ tour in which the U.S. will play various collegiate, professional and top club teams in preparation for the Olympics. Six Pac-12 schools, including UCLA and Arizona (which Team USA beat 5-4 on Feb. 18), will get the chance to face off against the Red, White and Blue. 
While the cross-country traveling and lack of school work — Garcia is redshirting this season with UCLA for a final year of collegiate eligibility in 2021 — are big perks of playing on the national team, Garcia said she’s had to get used to being more self-disciplined in the training room. 

“It’s a grind and you have to be motivated internally,” she said. “It’s the mentality of when you don’t have someone telling you what to do, you have to be prepared. Like in the weight room, you step into the weight room and you don’t have a coach telling you what to do. [You have to] be prepared, come up with your own workouts.” 

This summer marks the return of softball to the Olympics after being cut following the 2008 summer games in Beijing. The opportunity to be a part of the sport’s Olympic revival is something Garcia doesn’t take lightly as she knows it’s creating something powerful for future generations. 

“When it got taken out, it was devastating,” Garcia said. “It felt like it crushed a lot of little girls’ hearts just like mine. But now that we have this opportunity, I’m just super honored and humbled to be a part of this 2020 journey and just be among some of the best female athletes in this sport and to be that inspiration for the next group of girls.” 

Garcia is looking forward to facing the Bruins come Sunday. Through all the crazy madness that has been her life as of late, it’s the support of her teammates and UCLA coaches that has meant the most to her. 

“They have my back just as I have theirs,” she said. “Being able to hear from them that they are excited for me to be a part of this, to expand the sport of softball, that was probably the best moment.” 



Sunday, 11:30 a.m. 

 Big League Dreams Sports Park in Cathedral City, Calif. in the Mary Nutter Collegiate Classic 

 Flosoftball

2.tilte: Whicker: Will the last cut be the deepest for Fury against Wilder?
2.discription:
LAS VEGAS >> Tyson Fury got through 12 rounds against Deontay Wilder with skin and smile unbroken. 

He couldn’t get through three rounds against Otto Wallin without a cut that bled badly enough for sandbags. 
						
There were two cuts, actually, one over the right eye and one inside the eyelid. They needed 47 stitches and plastic surgery and on Saturday night they serve as a big “Hit One Here” sign, like the ones that used to be on baseball scoreboards, for Wilder in the WBC heavyweight champion rematch. 

A break in the levee could quickly dampen this occasion, which has whipped up a hype-storm worthy of  Floyd Mayweather days. It is a straight-up even fight between two undefeated heavyweights who already have given us one shining moment, over 14 months ago, at Staples Center. 
Fury and Wilder carried true malice into that fight, probably because Wilder did not take Fury seriously, probably because Fury was literally coming down from 400 pounds of body weight and maybe 800 pounds of depression and addiction. Fury then won more rounds than Wilder but had to accept a draw. 

Now it’s theatre. Fury and Wilder yell at each other like Willy Loman’s sons. Fortunately, nobody on this stage yells, “Cut!” 

“I was gone from the ring for three years and you still couldn’t knock me out,” Fury told Wilder at close range on Wednesday, before they pushed each other and were separated. Both were play-acting but the promoters are taking no chances. There was no staredown at Friday’s weigh-in. 

Fury has taken to calling Wilder “a big dosser,”  which is British slang for “bag lady.” His marketing touch has even produced a sport coat with “You Big Dosser” in vertical rows. 

That might not become a fashion staple. But Fury is firing all guns at once this weekend. He knows his career changes dramatically no matter the outcome. 
He is not pretending that the cut didn’t exist or won’t matter. Perhaps that is why Fury keeps bringing up a second-round knockout. He knows scar tissue does not have a long shelf life against Wilder 

“He can try to back me up,” Wilder said. “But can he do it, and if he does do it, how long can he continue? I don’t get credit for a lot of things. But one thing is for sure. I’m a great fighter going on my back feet. That’s when I can time you and set you up and run you into my own traps.” 

Wallin, 29, was 20-0 before Fury. For a second, he thought 21-0 was in the bag. But referee Tony Weeks and the ring doctors kept running Fury out there, and the Gypsy King won a unanimous decision (four, five and six points on the judges’ cards). Through the blood, Fury dubbed Wallin, from Sweden, “the Viking warrior.” 

“If you’ll watch the tape, I hit him, I saw the cut, and then I looked at my corner and said, ‘Yeah!’’’ Wallin said, pumping his fist. 

“It was a bad cut. In my mind the fight should have been stopped. But Fury is a warrior and he kept coming. There’s no way he was going to quit.” 

No, especially not with Wilder and a treasure chest over the next hill. There are disinterested parties who think the doctors would have retired Fury in a normal situation. 

“He (Fury) will have the cut on his mind,” Wallin said. “He also knows he got knocked down in the first fight. But I do think it would be a mistake for Wilder to target that cut. Fury has a lot of head movement and he’s a good counterpuncher. What Wilder probably should do is go to the body. And then they will adapt.” 

But “they” is different in this fight. Ben Davison was a Trainer of the Year candidate for the way he reshaped Fury the first time. Davison is gone. Fury said he wanted a more aggressive game plan but it didn’t help when Davison’s corner had trouble coagulating. 

The new trainer is SugarHill Steward, the nephew of the legendary trainer Emanuel. Actually his name was Javan “Sugar” Hill but he changed it because he said Emanuel was more of a father figure. 

Wilder interprets all this as a seed of turmoil. 

“You see a lot of nervous energy in his camp,” Wilder said. “He has a lot of things going on. He’s changing up so many things. You already know the saying. If it’s not broken, why fix it?” 

“I think Fury has more tools to work with,” Wallin said. “He’s a more versatile fighter. Wilder was impressive when he used to throw that jab, especially against Bermane Stiverne. But he hasn’t done it much lately. So let’s see what happens.” 

More to the point, let’s see what Fury can see.

3.tilte: UCLA men face Colorado for potential tiebreaker in Pac-12 standings
3.discription:
The Bruins have finally become the defensive team Coach Mick Cronin has been striving to turn them into all season. And it’s showing. 

At Utah on Thursday, UCLA prevented the Utes from making a 3-pointer until halfway through the second half, and Utah ended the game 3 for 12 from beyond the arc for its second-worst performance from distance during Pac-12 play this season. 
						
“Defensively, we couldn’t have played much better,” Cronin told reporters following 
UCLA is riding high, having won four in a row and eight of its last 10. In those eight wins, the Bruins have held opponents to an average of 59.1 points per game, improving their record to 15-0 when holding opposing teams to 73 points or fewer. 
“We haven’t changed anything,” sophomore guard David Singleton said at Thursday’s post-game press conference. “We’re just doing it better. We got used to Cronin’s style. To be honest, we started playing harder. We’re putting in more effort on defense, every game.” 

With its final out-of-state away game on Saturday afternoon at No. 18 Colorado, the Bruins (16-11, 9-5 Pac-12) are looking for their longest win streak of the season. 

A win over the Buffaloes would not only be UCLA’s first in Boulder since 2017, but securing the season sweep over Colorado would also give the Bruins the tiebreaker if the teams were to finish conference play with the same record. UCLA is tied with Oregon for fourth in the conference standings but sit just one game behind first-place Colorado (21-6, 10-4) with Arizona and Arizona State tied for second at 9-4 in Pac-12 play. The top four teams in the final standings get byes into the quarterfinals of next month’s Pac-12 Tournament in Las Vegas. 

Since its previous loss to UCLA, Colorado has won five of its last six games with its only loss coming against then-No. 17 Oregon 68-60 in Eugene. 

The Buffaloes are led by junior guards McKinley Wright (13.6 ppg) and Tyler Bey (13.5 ppg). Bey also leads the team and is tied atop the Pac-12 with 9.3 rebounds per game. 
The Bruins upset then-No. 20 Colorado 72-68 on Jan. 30 at Pauley Pavilion. Junior guard Chris Smith had a career-high 30 points in the program’s first win against a ranked team since Feb. 8, 2018. UCLA had a season-low eight assists but shot a season-best 86.2 from the free-throw line. 

 Saturday, 1 p.m. 

 Boulder, Colo. 

 CBS/Ch. 2, 1150 AM

4.tilte: Life for a lefty specialist like Dodgers’ Adam Kolarek could be changing this year
4.discription:
GLENDALE, Ariz. — When they came for the LOOGYs this winter, Adam Kolarek didn’t worry about it. He’s never seen himself that way. 

“When it was brought up last year, I kind of knew it was something that was going to be happening. Even in Triple-A, I figured it was going to happen. I just assumed it was already passed,” Kolarek said of the recently-ratified rule change which will require relief pitchers entering the game to face a minimum of three batters or complete an inning. 
						
“I think the main thing I’ve been telling people is until I came to L.A., I never thought of myself as a one-hitter guy. I was never used that way.” 

He was used that way by the Dodgers after being acquired from the Tampa Bay Rays in a midseason trade. Kolarek faced just one batter in 16 of his 26 appearances with the Dodgers in 2019 and two or fewer in 20 of the 26. In the postseason, he made three appearances against the Washington Nationals, faced left-handed Juan Soto each time and struck him out twice. 
Life as a LOOGY – the baseball acronym for Left-handed One-Out Guy – had its good points for Kolarek. 

“I enjoyed being available every night,” he said. “I knew looking at the lineup every night who I needed to prepare for mentally. 

“I think it’s going to be an adjustment for everybody.” 

In his career, Kolarek has held left-handed hitters to a .199 average with just 10 extra-base hits and only two home runs in 181 plate appearances. Despite his funky, sidearm delivery, right-handed hitters have been a lot more successful – a .299 average and .849 OPS. But Kolarek believes he has the weapons to get them out as well. 

“The main thing is I’ve always been a ground ball pitcher so I have to attack from the get-go,” he said. “Maybe the batting average against righties is a little higher than it is against lefties. But as long as I’m keeping it on the ground eventually that ball is going to be at somebody.” 
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts said the new rule has the Dodgers looking at ways to sequence pitches from a “lefty killer” like Kolarek – and a “righty” killer like Dylan Floro – to make them more effective against the opposite-handed batter. 

“Adam has been a lefty killer throughout his entire career. Now with the rule change, the challenge for him is to be able to feel confident in getting out a right-handed hitter,” Roberts said. “Now it’s kind of, ‘How do I attack right-handed hitters?’ 

“We’re going to give him every opportunity to face right-hand hitters to kind of see how that plays out, but I have every confidence that Adam will figure some things out and be effective against the right-handed hitter.” 

He wasn’t scheduled to throw a bullpen session on Friday. But Dodgers closer Kenley Jansen spent a good deal of time during the workout surrounded by instructors Rick Honeycutt, Joel Peralta and Orel Hershiser, throwing off a mound. 

“It happened you guys were there instead of watching David Price throw live BP,” Jansen teased with reporters afterward. “If you guys were watching David Price throw live BP, you probably wouldn’t know I was there.” 

Jansen’s work was focused on his slider. He said he tried three different grips during the session, finally finding a comfort level with one suggested by Hershiser and Honeycutt. 

“This is the perfect time to work on it,” Jansen said. “Why not take advantage of having those guys around?” 

Roberts said he has talked with Mookie Betts about where the new Dodger feels most comfortable batting in the lineup and Betts is expected to be the primary leadoff hitter this year. He could slip down to No.­ 2 against right-handed pitching, allowing Joc Pederson to bat leadoff. With the new three-batter minimum rule in place this year, opposing teams will have to think long and hard about bringing in a lefty specialist to face Pederson if it means leaving the lefty in to then face Betts and possibly Justin Turner. 

“Mookie has talked to me about wanting to hit at the top,” Roberts said. “That’s where he feels comfortable and that’s where we’re at right now.” 

Betts batted first or second in all of his 148 starts for the Red Sox last season and has highest OPS (.910) as a leadoff hitter in his career.

5.tilte: Sierra Canyon basketball defeats Etiwanda to reach third straight Open Division final
5.discription:
Support our high school sports coverage by becoming a digital subscriber. 
 When Sierra Canyon and Etiwanda faced each other on Dec. 28 in the Classic at Damien, it was anticipated to be a potential Open Division matchup. Almost two months later, that’s exactly what it was, and it certainly delivered. 
						
Sierra Canyon defeated Etiwanda 73-62 in front of a sold-out crowd at Calabasas High to advance to the CIF Southern Section Open Division final for the third consecutive season. 

It will be the second time in three years the Trailblazers will face Mater Dei in the championship game. It will be played at Long Beach State on Friday, Feb. 28 at 8:30 p.m. 
The game had multiple lead changes, high-flying dunks and plenty of drama, including a delay in the third quarter because of a scuffle in the stands that poured onto the court. The delay wasn’t longer than 10 minutes, but Sierra Canyon took advantage of the stoppage by going on a 17-5 run when play continued, creating a 54-42 lead late in the third frame that Etiwanda (28-3) couldn’t come back from. 

 
Sierra Canyon’s Ziaire Williams #1 shoots as Etiwanda’s Jaylen Clark #5 defends during their playoff game at Calabasas High in Calabasas, Friday, February 21, 2020.   (Photo by Hans Gutknecht, Los Angeles Daily News/SCNG)

Sierra Canyon’s Amari Bailey #10 pumps his fist as Ziaire Williams #1 hugs him after Bailey scored and was fouled during their playoff game at Calabasas High in Calabasas, Friday, February 21, 2020.   (Photo by Hans Gutknecht, Los Angeles Daily News/SCNG)
 
 
Sierra Canyon’s Amari Bailey #10 pumps his fist as Ziaire Williams #1 hugs him after Bailey scored and was fouled during their playoff game at Calabasas High in Calabasas, Friday, February 21, 2020.   (Photo by Hans Gutknecht, Los Angeles Daily News/SCNG)
 
 
“The delay really stopped our momentum,” Etiwanda’s Jaylen Clark said. “That was tough.” 

Etiwanda cut Sierra Canyon’s lead to 55-49 in the fourth quarter, but a corner 3-pointer from Bronny James in front of the Sierra Canyon bench ballooned the lead back to nine. 

“That was a huge shot,” Sierra Canyon coach Andre Chevalier said. 

Clark had 10 first-quarter points, including a corner 3-pointer that gave Etiwanda a 14-6 lead in front of its rambunctious traveling crowd. But Sierra Canyon used a 9-0 run to retake the lead behind transition baskets from Amari Bailey. 
After one tough finish, Bailey immediately began to chirp at the Etiwanda bench. A few possessions later Clark returned the favor with a tough finish of his own. 

Clark, a transfer from Corona Centennial who didn’t play in December’s first meeting, scored a game-high 32 points. 

“This was a great game,” Clark said. “Sierra Canyon was a great team. We still have more basketball to play. I’ll put this one behind me and move on.” 

Etiwanda made four 3s in the first half that helped the Eagles to a 34-31 lead a halftime, but those made 3s was something Sierra Canyon knew Etiwanda wasn’t particularly great at. 

“When they made those shots early, we knew it wouldn’t last,” Sierra Canyon’s Ziaire Williams said. “But it was harder for us to get in transition when they’re making shots. In the second half, they started missing those same shots and we were able to get out in transition.” 

Williams scored 23 points in the game, another high-level recruit who was unable to play in December’s victory over Etiwanda due to the transfer sit-out period. 

It’s the biggest game he’s played in his high school career after transferring from Notre Dame Sherman Oaks – which never got further than the second round in his three years there. 

“The game was crazy, but I just prepare like any other game,” Williams said. 

In the third quarter, only three Sierra Canyon players scored: Williams, Amari Bailey and BJ Boston. Boston totaled 19 and Bailey finished with 18. 

“Even when they were making shots, we stuck to the game plan,” Bailey said.

LOS ANGELES — If the season ended today, the Lakers and Grizzlies would be pitted in a first-round playoff series. The Lakers’ 3-0 season record against their challenger doesn’t inspire much hope for a competitive affair if it comes to fruition in April. 

But Friday night’s game, a 117-105 Lakers win at Staples Center, provided a snapshot of what Memphis (28-28) might offer in that potential 1-vs.-8 matchup – not experience, but energy. And the Lakers (42-12), who seemed perhaps a little too cool back from their All-Star break, need to bring some in return. 

The Lakers were up by 25 early in the third quarter, on their way to an apparent blowout, but the Grizzlies whittled that to as few as four points in a tighter-than-hoped fourth. It forced LeBron James (32 points, 10 for 11 from the free-throw line) and Anthony Davis (28 points) to play deep into a game when they might have otherwise been able to watch from the bench and forced the Lakers to find the gear they were on before their time off last week. 

To say the result was in doubt might be an overstatement – but it wasn’t completely assured until James scored back-to-back baskets within the final two minutes: a tough layup in traffic and a turnaround baseline jumper. On the next possession, Davis made a 3-pointer and held his hands high on the follow-through while exhaling with relief. 
The Lakers are likely to need tougher resolve as soon as Sunday, with an afternoon game scheduled against the Boston Celtics (39-16) who stomped them back in January. 

“The worst loss of the season for us, we didn’t play our best at all,” Davis said. “So we remember that for sure. We feel like we owe them.” 

James and Davis, who had the least time off because of their All-Star weekend obligations, looked the most like themselves. James was the main force in gathering up the early lead, including a memorable first-quarter dunk off a Danny Green lob. 

Davis might have made his biggest impact on defense, where he racked up seven blocked shots, frustrating Grizzlies drivers for much of the night. He also worked the glass for 13 rebounds on a night when the Lakers’ traditional centers struggled to make an impact with foul trouble. He scored 24 of his 28 points, grabbed 11 of his 13 rebounds and blocked five of his seven shots in the second half. 

It drummed up more talk from the Lakers that Davis should be the front-runner for Defensive Player of the Year, which Davis acknowledged is part of his motivation – but not all. 
“I would love to have that award several times before I retire – which is not soon,” he quipped. “But I think just trying to set a standard for one myself and two, my team on the defensive end and the rest of the guys will follow and I’m just trying to help guys on their beat.” 

The Grizzlies’ effort came on a night when the Lakers effectively corralled their rookie star Ja Morant, holding the springy dunker to 17 points (5-for-14 shooting) and three assists. The franchise’s other young pillar, Jaren Jackson Jr., left the game with left knee soreness after just 16 minutes of play. 

But the Lakers’ own attack looked unsteady against Memphis’ determined defense: They shot only 3 for 11 from 3-point range after halftime. The exceptions were Avery Bradley (14 points) and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope (12 points). Alex Caruso gave the Lakers a two-way boost in the closing lineup, adding nine points including a putback dunk of a missed free throw over a helpless Kyle Anderson. 

A recent rotation change has Caruso (nine points) playing more minutes late in the second and fourth quarters in the Lakers’ closing group. Statistics indicate that he’s one of James’ best partners. 

“There’s the eye test, but LeBron and Alex is one of our best combinations throughout the season from a net rating standpoint,” Coach Frank Vogel said. “We’ll continue to explore ways that that’s getting out there enough without overdoing it. The last two games he’s just been playing out of his mind.” 

The Lakers had a brief scare in the first quarter, when Davis took a knee in the back of his right calf from one of the Memphis players. He subbed out of the game in the first minute, then headed to the locker room after the first timeout. 

It wasn’t until the 8:48 mark of the second quarter that Davis strode back onto the bench, then quickly checked back in. He ended up playing 31 minutes. 

Davis said he felt pain in the calf when he was sitting, but as he played, he got warmer and felt better. 

“If guys can’t go, it’s next-man-up mentality, and I think we did that tonight when I went out,” he said. “But we don’t, if guys feel like they’re able to play, then, by all means, we’re going to be on the floor. We’re trying to set a culture, set a standard for ourselves that is going to get us into a rhythm heading into the playoffs.” 

That’s the goal, which Vogel emphasized again on Friday. The Lakers are on pace to earn the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference, and their priorities will start shifting to maintaining health and rhythm in the final run of the regular season. 

So yes, he acknowledged, potential playoff matchups like the Grizzlies are “in the back of our minds,” but first things come first. 

“The answers reveal themselves after the fact,” he said. “We’re not thinking about playoffs tonight. We’re thinking about getting one win.” 

.

7.tilte: Report: Lakers to waive DeMarcus Cousins, hope to add Markieff Morris
7.discription:
LOS ANGELES — On Friday evening, just as he has for almost every day this season, DeMarcus Cousins showed up for work. 

He hugged employees on his way to the locker room roughly two hours before tip-off against the Memphis Grizzlies. Then he sat inside under the locker bearing his last name. While he has not played this season since tearing his left ACL, Cousins has been a consistent presence around the team – even on trips. 
						
It’s likely one of the last such days Cousins will have this season as a Laker: Multiple media reports indicate the team is making a move in the buyout market, intending to add forward Markieff Morris if he clears waivers on Sunday, and waiving Cousins to create the necessary roster spot. 

The Athletic reported that Morris was entering the market after agreeing to a buyout with the Detroit Pistons on Friday. ESPN was first to report that Cousins, a former All-Star who was injured in August, would be cut to make room for an addition the Lakers hope can bolster their frontcourt for the postseason. 
The Lakers declined to officially comment, with Coach Frank Vogel saying: “I don’t have any comment about rumors or reports.” 

Morris is the latest chess move as Western Conference contenders have worked to improve their rosters for the playoffs, but it’s the first addition the Lakers have made during the season. The Clippers added veteran guard Reggie Jackson and Morris’ twin brother, Marcus; the Rockets added veterans Robert Covington, Jeff Green and Demarre Carroll. Morris could still be claimed by another team with cap space – or trade exceptions – off waivers before Sunday. 

Morris, 30, was averaging 11 points and 3.9 rebounds while shooting 39.7 percent from 3-point range in 44 games for the Pistons, who have torn down their roster for a full rebuild. Over nine seasons, he has averaged 11.6 points, 5.4 rebounds and 1.7 assists in 623 games while shooting 34.5 percent from beyond the arc. The Athletic reported that Morris was told the Lakers would use him as a reserve power forward, potentially freeing up Kyle Kuzma to see more minutes at small forward. 

The Lakers were in the running to add Morris last season, when he was bought out by the Washington Wizards, but he instead signed with the Oklahoma City Thunder. 

Morris reportedly is leaving $4.3 million, the remainder of this season and his 2020-21 salary, on the table, according to ESPN. The Lakers can use a $1.75 million exception, awarded by the NBA when Cousins suffered his injury, to help sign Morris – significantly higher than the veteran’s minimum. 
A subplot of the potential move is a rivalry between the twin Morris brothers for the Los Angeles franchises. At Clippers practice on Friday, Marcus Morris said he’d still support his brother even though he would be playing for the Lakers. 

“I’m gonna be in Staples Center all the time,” he said. “I think maybe to y’all it might be weird that I’m going to all his games, but that’s what’ll probably happen. And we’ll probably get a house together.” 

As recently as Thursday, the Lakers addressed questions as to whether Cousins, a popular player in the Lakers locker room, would be ready for the playoffs. 
The move seems to acknowledge that Cousins’ medical progress didn’t look good to return this year. Vogel said that it wouldn’t be “ideal” for the 29-year-old to be finding his rhythm again during the postseason. 

The New York Times reported that Cousins, if he is not picked up by another team, might be permitted to continue rehabbing his injury at the Lakers’ practice facility. 

The Lakers originally signed Cousins in July, hoping the former All-Star’s bond with Anthony Davis would lead to something special. Cousins came in with injury concerns, suffering an Achilles rupture in 2018 when he played with Davis and the New Orleans Pelicans, and tearing his left quadriceps in the middle of Golden State’s 2019 postseason run. 

The move comes as Cousins made his first public comments about his injury and his offseason misdemeanor domestic violence allegation (since dismissed) on a podcast earlier in the week. On “All The Smoke” with former NBA players Steven Jackson and Matt Barnes, Cousins said: “I said the wrong thing. Heat of the moment, we’ve all done it.”

8.tilte: Charisma Osborne scores 32 to lead UCLA women’s basketball past Washington State
8.discription:
PULLMAN, Wash. — UCLA coach Cori Close had one thing to say about her team’s come-from-behind win over Washington State: Thank goodness for Charisma Osborne. 

“We were in a heap of trouble if it weren’t for Charisma,” Close said. “The bottom line is though, I’m bringing the joy because we found a way.” 
						
Osborne had a career-high 32 points and 11 rebounds and No. 8 UCLA rallied in the fourth quarter and beat Washington State 70-62 Friday night. 

Trailing 61-57 with 3:30 remaining, Osborne was fouled on a 3-point attempt. She made all three free throws, pulling the Bruins within a point. 
Kiana Jefferson made two baskets and Osborne hit a jumper with 1:14 left to close out the Cougars. 

The Bruins (23-3, 12-3 Pac-12) won despite shooting just 34% from the field and committing 17 turnovers. UCLA improved to 23-8 all-time in Pullman and has won consecutive games following an 80-66 home loss to No. 3 Oregon on Feb. 14. 

Osborne, who averages 14 points, posted a career high in scoring for the second straight game. She put up 22 points in the Bruins’ 83-74 overtime win over No. 15 Oregon State on Monday. 

Osborne shot 11 of 21 against Washington State and recorded her third double-double of the season. She was the only Bruins player to score in double figures. 

Borislava Hristova scored 29 points for Washington State (11-16, 4-11 Pac-12), which lost its fourth straight. Hristova went down with what appeared to be a leg injury with a little over a minute to play. She returned after being checked out in the locker room. Chanelle Molina added 15 points and nine rebounds for the Cougars. 
“Well, I feel a lot of emotion right now. Just really proud of our team and how hard they played. Their start of the game was unbelievable energy wise and we really had tremendous effort by Bobby and Molina, two kids who you would expect it from as seniors,” said WSU Coach Kamie Ethridge. “This was just a really good UCLA team that has so many weapons that it is hard to hold them down for an entire game.” 

UCLA shot 25% in the first quarter as Washington State jumped out to a 19-11 lead behind Hristova’s 11 points. Washington State center Bella Murekatete had four steals and the Cougars forced nine turnovers on a UCLA team that averages 11.4 per game. 

UCLA cut the Washington State lead to 34-31 in the second quarter as Osborne took control, scoring 12 of her team’s 20 points on 5-of-7 shooting. 

UCLA took its first lead when Michaela Onyenwere scored a layup off a fast break, making the score 39-38 with 6:49 left in the third. 

 With South Carolina, Baylor and Oregon having established themselves as the three best teams in the country, UCLA is in a crowded field competing for the final No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament. The Bruins have only one marquee non-conference win (at Indiana) and their three remaining games are against teams in the bottom half of the Pac-12 standings. They will need a convincing finish to the regular season to make their case for the final top seed in March. 

 The Cougars have lost 34 straight games against Top-25 ranked teams. They are currently 7-7 when playing in Pullman and will have one more opportunity, on Sunday against USC, to secure their first winning season at home since 2016-2017. 

 At Washington on Sunday. 

 Host USC on Sunday.
